page.title: 04THE ECOLOGY OF SHALBOURNE-2
page.content: The farmland provides rich feeding for flocks of rooks, jackdaws and collared doves and for visiting hordes of wild pigeon; in winter these are often joined by large groups of plover, fieldfare and redwing. Predators include kestrel and sparrow hawks, magpies and jays with passing buzzards and an occasional hobby. A shallow brook provides a passage for migrants such as sandpipers, greenshanks, water rail, warblers and flycatchers. Snipe and many duck are winter residents. All the common{butterflies}are found - some 22 species. Among the numerous {moth population}there are at least 6 varieties of hawk moths.{Wildflowers abound in hedges and roadside verges which have benefitted from economies in public services but which are always at risk from some careless use of farming sprays.
